description:
Allokutzneria multivorans is a species of bacteria that belongs to the Actinobacteria class. It is a Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, and aerobic bacterium. The cells of A. multivorans are typically rod-shaped and can form branched filaments.

This species was first isolated from soil samples collected in China. It is capable of degrading and utilizing a variety of organic compounds, including various carbohydrates, as its sole carbon and energy sources. This metabolic versatility is reflected in its species name "multivorans," which means "able to consume many different substances."

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequence comparisons has shown that A. multivorans is closely related to other members of the Allokutzneria genus, which are known to be widely distributed in various environmental habitats, such as soil and freshwater sediments.

Further studies on the physiological and genomic characteristics of A. multivorans may provide insights into its ecological role and potential applications in areas such as bioremediation or biotechnology.
